Key Arguments: The legislation is ineffective and harmful to democratic freedoms.
Government should not police public speech in the modern global context.
Legal approaches to controlling speech have negative outcomes for democracy.
The legislation will lead to censorship and restrict freedom of speech.
The proposal will be exploited by activists and political agitants.
Market forces, not government regulation, should dictate platform success.
Excessive penalties and litigation costs prevent justice.
The government lacks the legal authority to regulate opinions.
The legislation will be ignored or lead to restricted content in Australia.
Misinformation and disinformation are transient and should not be legislated against.
ACMA is not equipped to handle the proposed responsibilities.
Notable Quotes: The proposed legislation is not only of dubious validity, it will be ineffective against its stated aims while doing harm to that which it claims to protect.
Citizens of this world have access to far more diverse and disparate information feeds and viewpoints than was the case even a mere 40 years ago.

The real-world experience of controls implemented against speech and/or publishers by the United Russia Party, the Chinese Communist Party, and the National Socialist German Workers Party run counter to Australian society.
The contemporary terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are euphemistic issues to enable censorship actions.
